sessions.description: Enjoy some light snacks while you register for the workshop day!
sessions.title: Breakfast & Registration

sessions.description: Bon appetit!
sessions.title: Lunch

sessions.description: Everyone’s invited! Come meet the team, collect your badge, and get to know your fellow conference attendees.
sessions.title: RWConnect Opening Reception & Early Registration

sessions.description: Enjoy a light breakfast while you pick up your RWDevCon 2018 badge!
sessions.title: Breakfast & Registration

sessions.description: Bon appetit!
sessions.title: Lunch

sessions.description: Do you like board games? Stop by the Board Game Zone during day 1 and day 2 lunch, play some games led by our volunteers, and make some new friends! This is a guided activity that is great for both introverts and extroverts.
sessions.title: RWConnect Board Game Zone

sessions.description: On Day 1 (Friday) during lunch, meet and greet with fellow women who code for an informal discussion! :]
sessions.title: RWConnect Women's Meetup

sessions.description: Want to bring your family with you to the conference? Our volunteers are organizing some fun family activities for families to enjoy together in Washington D.C. while you are at the conference. Just meet in the lobby at 9:30AM sharp each day!
sessions.title: RWConnect Family Fun Day

sessions.description: Sleep is overrated. Join your fellow attendees in coming up with ideas, testing your skills, and collaborating on a new project. A hackathon is a perfect way to see just how much you can get accomplished in a short period of time. Code for as long or as little as you like – go all night if you wish!
sessions.title: RWConnect Hackathon

sessions.description: Enjoy a light breakfast while you pick up your RWDevCon 2018 badge!
sessions.title: Breakfast & Registration

sessions.description: Want to bring your family with you to the conference? Our volunteers are organizing some fun family activities for families to enjoy together in Washington D.C. while you are at the conference. Just meet in the lobby at 9:30AM sharp each day!
sessions.title: RWConnect Family Fun Day

sessions.description: Bon appetit!
sessions.title: Lunch

sessions.description: Do you like board games? Stop by the Board Game Zone during day 1 and day 2 lunch, play some games led by our volunteers, and make some new friends! This is a guided activity that is great for both introverts and extroverts.
sessions.title: RWConnect Board Game Zone

sessions.description: Join James Dempsey on Saturday night for the RWConnect Trivia Night! Split into small teams to answer iOS, Swift, and Apple trivia questions to win “optional prizes” - which could be an amazing prize, or could be nil!
sessions.title: RWConnect Trivia Night

sessions.description: Get an overview of the new RWConnect Open Spaces event coming this afternoon, and learn how you can be a part of it!

speakers.bio: DevRel @particle | Founder of @CarrotPantsPub ðŸ¥•ðŸ‘–| writer, speaker, maker & optimistic nay-sayer | My spirit animal is a 555 timer chip
speakers.name: Brandon Satrom

sessions.title: RWConnect Open Spaces Introduction

sessions.description: Connect with other conference attendees on the topics you’re most passionate about! Topics will be proposed and led by fellow attendees, and they are a great way to share what you’ve learned, and learn from others.
sessions.title: RWConnect Open Spaces

sessions.description: Join Dru & Janie in a special live recording of a raywenderlich.com podcast episode!
sessions.title: raywenderlich.com Live Podcast

sessions.description: Join us at the Carlyle Club, an old-school supper club right across the street from the hotel. There will be delicious food, an open bar, and an awesome stage perfect for the ultimate RWDevCon show: RWConnect Trivia Night! Must be 21 or over.
sessions.title: RWDevCon Party

sessions.description: RWDevCon has a special event at the end of the conference you won’t want to miss, so make sure you stay till the end... or don’t cry to us later!
sessions.title: Concluding Remarks

sessions.description: It’s so hard to say goodbye. We ease the pain with one last chance to mix and mingle with the speakers and the new friends you’ve met!
sessions.title: RWConnect Closing Receptions

sessions.description: This is a short welcome for the pre-conference workshop attendees, to explain the basics of the conference. The full opening remarks and keynote come on Friday!
sessions.title: Workshop Welcoming Remarks

sessions.description: In this workshop, you’ll construct your own collection type and do a deep dive into the semantics, performance, and expectations of each Swift collection protocol. In the second half of the workshop, you’ll explore ways to write your code that takes advantage of this new knowledge. You’ll walk away with advanced knowledge and techniques that will augment your daily Swift development.

speakers.bio:
Kelvin is a Swift Developer. He currently maintains the Swift Algorithm Club. In his free time, he dabbles in web development and server side Swift.

Outside of programming work, he's an aspiring entrepreneur. You can find him on his twitter at @KelvinlauKL
speakers.name: Kelvin Lau

speakers.bio:
Vincent is a writer, guitarist, and developer. He currently works at Capital One as an iOS developer.

When Vincent is not working he enjoys coding for fun, playing video games, enjoying time with family and friends and golfing. With hard work and dedication he hopes to one day become a golfer to play in small tournaments.
speakers.name: Vincent Ngo

sessions.title: Swift Algorithms Workshop

sessions.description: Have you been working with iOS for a few years now but always been a little bit too nervous to jump into Instruments and try to track down some problems in your app? Maybe I’m way o  and you’re a little newer to the game and you’re just really interested in trying to improve your app’s performance. Either way, by the end of this workshop you’ll have a good feel for how to use Instruments to dive deep into what’s happening while your app is working and see exactly where the bottlenecks are.

speakers.bio:
Luke is currently an iOS developer at Fyusion.
Sometimes he tweets and blogs.

He basically speaks in references so if you catch one be sure to let him know.
speakers.name: Luke Parham

sessions.title: Practical Instruments Workshop

sessions.description: With Apple’s new CoreML and Vision frameworks, you can now add machine learning AI to your apps. In this hands-on workshop, you’ll learn what machine learning actually is, how to train a model, and integrate it into an app.

speakers.bio:
Prior to software development, Patrick played Chess professionally. Chess sparked his deep interest in pattern recognition & artificial Intelligence.

He went on to study Bioinformatics & Computer Science. During his studies, he worked with leading scientists to build novel analysis software for biomedical research. He then founded, Expat Inc, to find ways to make such innovations available at an affordable price to all. He now holds several granted & pending machine learning patents. They leverage them to power, Stock Market Sensei, a transparent daily stock analysis platform in use by thousands.

His mobile development experience has primarily been in building apps from scratch to revenue.
speakers.name: Patrick Kwete

speakers.bio: Audrey Tam retired at the end of 2012 from a 25-year career as a computer science academic. Her teaching included Pascal, C/C++, Java, Java web services, web app development in php and mysql, user interface design and evaluation, and iOS programming. Before moving to Australia, she worked on Fortran and PL/1 simulation software at IBM's development lab in Silicon Valley. Audrey now teaches short courses in iOS app development to non-programmers, and attends nearly all Melbourne Cocoaheads monthly meetings.
speakers.name: Audrey Tam

sessions.title: Machine Learning Workshop

sessions.description: If you watched that stunning augmented reality (AR) demonstration at WWDC 2017 and thought “I’d like to make apps like that someday,” “someday” starts at this workshop. You’ll learn about the features of Apple’s ARKit augmented reality framework, harness data from the camera and your users’ motions, present information and draw images over real-world scenes, and make the world your View Controller!

speakers.bio:
Joey landed his first programming job in the ’90s with a HyperCard (remember that?) resume and by going out for beer with the managers of the company where he wanted to work until they caved and hired him.

Since then, he’s worked at a San Francisco startup during the dot-com bubble, done tech evangelism for Tucows, Microsoft, and Shopify, valiantly tried to make Windows Phone happen, and once had a very short stint as an accordion-playing go-go dancer at a Toronto nightclub. He’s currently the Lead Product Manager at Sourcetoad.

Joey lives, works, and engages in nincompoopery in Tampa, Florida, where he runs Tampa iOS Meetup (and helps out at the Android and Xamarin Meetups, too!), plays unlikely rock and pop tunes on his accordion, and generally does what he can to avoid becoming a “Florida Man” news story.
speakers.name: Joey deVilla

sessions.title: ARKit Workshop

sessions.description: Ray and Vicki will kick off the conference, and Tammy Coron will deliver the keynote with a talk titled "The Red Thread of Fate".

speakers.bio: Ray is part of a great team - the raywenderlich.com team, a group of over 100 developers and editors from across the world. He and the rest of the team are passionate both about making apps and teaching others the techniques to make them. When Rayâ€™s not programming, heâ€™s probably playing video games, role playing games, or board games.
speakers.name: Ray Wenderlich

speakers.bio: Vicki is Rayâ€™s wife and business partner. She is a digital artist who creates illustrations, game art, and a lot of other art or design work for the tutorials and books on raywenderlich.com. She also runs gameartguppy.com, which is a website where she creates free and and inexpensive art assets for game developers to use in their games. When sheâ€™s not making art, she loves hiking, a good glass of wine, and attempting to create the perfect cheese plate.
speakers.name: Vicki Wenderlich

speakers.bio:
Writer • Illustrator • Developer • Speaker

Tammy Coron is an independent creative professional and the host of Roundabout: Creative Chaos. She's also the co-founder of Day Of The Indie, the organizer behind Indie DevStock, and the founder of Just Write Code.

For more information, visit TammyCoron.com.
speakers.name: Tammy Coron

sessions.title: Keynote & Opening Remarks

sessions.description: Learn how to make and manage a Living Style Guide for your application, which can show all of the building blocks for your application both in and out of context. With a Living Style Guide, you always have a quick way to view the building blocks of your application, the ability to build out new views quickly and consistently, and the power to make changes in one place which are re ected throughout your whole app.

speakers.bio:
Ellen Shapiro is the Lead Mobile Developer for SpotHero in Chicago, Illinois. She is working in her spare time to help bring Hum to life. She’s also developed several independent applications through her personal company, Designated Nerd Software.

When she's not writing code, she's usually tweeting about it.
speakers.name: Ellen Shapiro

sessions.title: Living Style Guides

sessions.description: Swift 4 introduced the Codable API and compiler support for simplifying how serialization is done and for supporting all Swift types including value types such as enums and structs. This session will cover strategies for using Codable to build models for real world RESTful JSON APIs. But that’s not all. Once your models are Codable, you can leverage this machinery to go beyond JSON. Find out how in this session.

speakers.bio:
Ray Fix is using Swift to help create Revolve--the next generation in research microscopy at Echo. He also serves as the iOS tutorials topics master at RayWenderlich.com.

Ray is mostly-fluent in spoken and written Japanese and stays healthy by walking, jogging, and playing ultimate frisbee. When he is not doing one of those things, he is writing and dreaming of code in Swift. よろしくお願い致します。
speakers.name: Ray Fix

sessions.title: Swift 4 Serialization

sessions.description: Modularity in code goes hand-in-hand with readability, testablity, reusability, scalability, and reliability, along with many other ilities. This session covers how to make modules, figure out what code goes in a module, and then how to use those modules for maximum success. You’ll learn best practices in code encapsulation and reuse, learn some programming buzz words, and level up your Xcode skills.

speakers.bio: Michael Katz envisions a world where mobile apps always work, respect users’ privacy, and integrate well with their users’ life. When not coding, he can be found with his family playing board games, brewing, gardening, and watching the Yankees.
speakers.name: Mike Katz

sessions.title: Architecting Modules

sessions.description: Netflix remains the leader in the binge-watching, evening-wasting habits of modern TV viewers. How hard could it be to copy this model? Quite hard, as it turns out. In this session, you’ll learn how to solve challenges unique to the architecture and construction of video streaming apps. You’ll discover some interesting iOS features you weren’t aware of before, and how to use these in your own apps.

speakers.bio:
Sam is a strange mashup of developer, writer and trainer. By day you'll find him recording videos for Razeware, writing tutorials, attending conferences and generally being a good guy. By night he's likely to be out entertaining people, armed with his trombone and killer dance moves.

He'd like it very much if you were to follow him on twitter at @iwantmyrealname, seek him out as sammyd on GitHub, or check his personal site iwantmyreal.name.
speakers.name: Sam Davies

sessions.title: Building a Video Player App

sessions.description: Auto Layout takes effort to learn, and can be notoriously painful to do so. But once you have the basics, how can you become efficient at applying, editing and debugging constraints? In this session we will examine some best practices for AutoLayout, looking at examples via Interface Builder and in code. The session will focus primarily on AutoLayout for iOS.

speakers.bio: Gemma has been an iOS Developer since 2009 and loves travel, coffee, wine and code. Originally from Melbourne, Australia, she now resides in fabulous Brooklyn. She spends her 9-5 as an Engineering Manager at Etsy, looking after the 'Buy on Etsy' mobile apps.
speakers.name: Gemma Barlow

sessions.title: Auto Layout Best Practices

sessions.description: Architecture is the design of functional, safe, sustainable and aesthetically pleasing software. There are many ways to architect your applications like the common MVC, MVP and MVVM patterns. This session will get you comfortable with clean architecture and show you how to transform a basic application built using MVC to a clean architecture using VIPER that is scalable.

speakers.bio: Anthony is a Lead iOS Engineer at Globant and the recruiter for RayWenderlich.com. In his spare time he likes to play golf, go see a movie at least once a week, continue to learn and spend time with his family.
speakers.name: Anthony Lockett

sessions.title: Clean Architecture on iOS

sessions.description: We have a ton of tools at our disposal when we program. We also have a tenaciousness to spend most of our lives on things that don’t work. Finally, some of us also have a superpower: We remember to step back from our app and look at it from the user’s point of view. In this talk we apply our tools, tenaciousness, and superpower to the game of life.

speakers.bio: Dad, husband, and storyteller...Podcaster,writer and editor.
speakers.name: Daniel Steinberg

sessions.title: The Game of Life

sessions.description: As individuals we - implicitly or explicitly - define success, as do teams. But how do these definitions and incentives impact how and what we build? Let's talk about the ways in which the dysfunctions of your organization become the dysfunctions of your product.

speakers.bio: just a girl, standing in front of a raccoon, asking for an adventure
speakers.name: Cate Huston

sessions.title: Successfully Derailed Product

sessions.description: Kitura is the REST API framework in Swift written by IBM, and has been in development since Swift was open sourced. In this workshop, Iâ€™ll get you started with a fully functional API using the latest and greatest features of Swift. Youâ€™ll have an API that uses Codable for GET, POST, and DELETE requests - simplifying the code you have to write. Finally, Iâ€™ll introduce you to Kituraâ€™s new ORM feature, which builds on top of Codable to make saving data even easier than before!

speakers.bio: Swift and other things at @IBM, organizer of @swiftcloudshop and @weirdswiftatx. I have been told that I have a very large microphone attached to my desk.
speakers.name: David Okun

sessions.title: Server Side Swift with Kitura

sessions.description: Learn the fundamentals of Android development through this tutorial. You’ll build an app from scratch that walks you through Android layout, resources, list views, navigation, networking and material design. Along the way, I’ll compare and contrast the concepts with those found in building iOS apps.

speakers.bio: Christine is an Engineer on the Developer Advocacy team at Facebook. In this role, she is focused on helping grow the mobile developer ecosystem with emphasis on Android, iOS, and the mobile web. Prior to Facebook, Christine headed up engineering at Mshift, a mobile banking software provider, delivering iPhone apps and mobile browser-based products.
speakers.name: Christine Abernathy

sessions.title: Android for iOS Developers

sessions.description: When you’re asked to include charts or graphs in an app, don’t panic and reach for a third- party library. In this session you’ll learn how to make your own fancy-looking data visualisations, with animations and color e ects as a bonus!

speakers.bio: Richard is an iOS developer for MartianCraft, prolific Stack Overflow participant and author of a development blog, Command Shift. When he's not in front of a computer he is usually building Lego horse powered spaceships (don't ask!) with his daughter.
speakers.name: Rich Turton

sessions.title: The Art of the Chart

sessions.description: Have you ever run into a legacy app with a Massive View Controller or other architectural problems? In this session, you’ll learn how to give legacy apps a spring cleaning. You’ll learn how to iteratively split apart code, add testing, and prevent problems from happening again.

speakers.bio: iOS and Android tech lead at Novoda, speaker, and tech editor on this here website, Ray Wenderlich!
speakers.name: Alex Curran

sessions.title: Spring Cleaning Your App

sessions.description: Automated testing tools for iOS have come a long way since the initial release of the iPhone SDK. Learn how to improve your app’s quality by using TDD to build both the model and user interface layers of an application. You’ll learn what TDD is, how it can be used in unit tests to verify simple model objects, code that uses a remote API, and user interface code. Plus: some tricks for writing tests easier!

speakers.bio:
iOS Team Lead for raywenderlich.com

Andy loves writing iOS applications, being a dad, doing anything outside, and playing guitar. He realizes there's always room for improvement, and thus is always trying to get better at what he does.

When not working on raywenderlich.com, he blogs in the minor leagues at cleanswifter.com.
speakers.name: Andy Obusek

sessions.title: Improving App Quality with Test Driven Development

sessions.description: In this session, you will learn how to use WKWebView to embed HTML that looks seamless with iOS native controls. This can save a lot of time by not having to build storyboards (or UI) for substantial areas of your apps, and you can even repurpose the same content in Android. Learn how to structure CSS/fonts, intercept hyperlink taps, integrate Javascript with Swift, and more!

speakers.bio: Eric Soto is a Professional Software Engineer and certified Agile-Scrum Master specializing in Apple iOS and macOS Apps. He is based in Palm Beach Florida, and routinely works with clients all across the US including many major brands. During his 30 year career, Eric has accumulated extensive experience in REST APIs, web applications, server back-end systems, automated infrastructure deployments and more. Learn more at ericsoto.net.
speakers.name: Eric Soto

sessions.title: Advanced WKWebView

sessions.description: In the past few years, a number of examples of Clean Architecture on Android have been presented within the Android community. This session will discuss some of the history and theory behind Clean Architecture, show an example app use case from the “outside-in”, and then demonstrate the development of a new app use case from the “inside-out”.

speakers.bio: Joe’s path to software development began in the fields of computational physics and systems engineering. He has been a mobile software developer on iOS and Android since 2009. He now lives in Boston and is Android Team Lead for raywenderlich.com.
speakers.name: Joe Howard

sessions.title: Clean Architecture on Android

sessions.description: If you watched that stunning augmented reality (AR) demonstration at WWDC 2017 and thought “I’d like to make apps like that someday,” “someday” starts at this workshop. You’ll learn about the features of Apple’s ARKit augmented reality framework, harness data from the camera and your users’ motions, present information and draw images over real-world scenes, and make the world your View Controller!

speakers.bio:
Joey landed his first programming job in the ’90s with a HyperCard (remember that?) resume and by going out for beer with the managers of the company where he wanted to work until they caved and hired him.

Since then, he’s worked at a San Francisco startup during the dot-com bubble, done tech evangelism for Tucows, Microsoft, and Shopify, valiantly tried to make Windows Phone happen, and once had a very short stint as an accordion-playing go-go dancer at a Toronto nightclub. He’s currently the Lead Product Manager at Sourcetoad.

Joey lives, works, and engages in nincompoopery in Tampa, Florida, where he runs Tampa iOS Meetup (and helps out at the Android and Xamarin Meetups, too!), plays unlikely rock and pop tunes on his accordion, and generally does what he can to avoid becoming a “Florida Man” news story.
speakers.name: Joey deVilla

sessions.title: Getting Started with ARKit

sessions.description: Learn three different ways of creating and manipulating custom views. First, learn how to supercharge your IB through code and create unique views using storyboards. Next, dive into creating flexible and reusable views. Finally, bring it all together with some CoreGraphics and CoreAnimation pizazz!

speakers.bio: Lea is a Product Manager for mobile at Rent the Runway. She writes about iOS, UX and UI, teaches iOS classes at GA and volunteers for Girls Who Code. In her free time she plays piano, and tries to use code and technology to make art. Or she just doodles and listens to MIKA.
speakers.name: Lea Marolt Sonnenschein

sessions.title: Custom Views

sessions.description: Building an iOS app is easy. Building a successful one however needs more effort. This session will focus on automating your builds, using continuous integration to test and deploy them, and finally integrating analytics and tracking once your app is released to prepare for the next iteration. You will walk away with a toolset for building an efficient app development workflow.

speakers.bio: Namrata is a Mobile Developer at Stagename doing native Android and iOS development. Apart from developing apps, she is passionate about travelling, food and hiking with her dog. You can reach out to her on Twitter, LinkedIn or follow her on GitHub.
speakers.name: Namrata Bandekar

sessions.title: App Development Workflow

sessions.description: Metal is a low level framework that allows you to control your code down to the bit level. However, many common operations don’t require you to get down to that level because they are handled by Core Image and SceneKit. This session will show you what operations you get with SceneKit and how you can go deeper with Metal when you need to without losing the convenience of SceneKit.

speakers.bio: I am a consultant, author, and speaker from Madison, WI. I am the coauthor of the Swift Apprentice and the iOS SDK books from the Pragmatic Programmers. I blog random thoughts at http://redqueencoder.com. I live with an attempted grumble of pugs.
speakers.name: Janie Clayton

sessions.title: Integrating Metal Shaders with SceneKit

sessions.description: As an iOS developer, the most important tool you use is Xcode. Learn how to supercharge your e ciency with various tips and tricks.

speakers.bio: Jawwad is a freelance iOS Developer interested in the Healthcare and Education space (and is currently available for contract work). He enjoys teaching and was the original founder of the of the NYC iOS Study Group. He's worked for companies as large as The New York Times, and as small as GateGuru, a 6 person startup.
speakers.name: Jawwad Ahmad

sessions.title: Xcode Tips & Tricks

sessions.description: In this tutorial we will combine all the cutting edge architecture design techniques such as reactive programming, dependency injection, protocol oriented programming, unidirectional data flow, use cases, and more in order to master the art of designing codebases that can easily change over time. Learn what causes code to change, how to minimize the effort to deal with those changes, and how to apply this in your own apps (such as switching from RxSwift to ReactiveSwift, from Core Data to Realm, or from one view implementation to another!)

speakers.bio:
Rene is an iOS Client Architect at Atlassian, where he is known for his expertise in user interface engineering with UIKit, Core Animation, and Core Graphics. He has been engineering iOS apps since 2009.

When he's not coding, René loves to snow ski, ocean kayak, and root for the Texas Longhorns.
speakers.name: Rene Cacheaux

sessions.title: Advanced Unidirectional Architecture

sessions.description: We all have things that make us unique: from our experiences and our interests, to our own bodies and minds. Many of these things we hang on a coat rack when we sit down in a cube or in front of a computer. Some of these things we view as assets and others we view as detriments. Learning how to accept and leverage all of them can make us more versatile and more creative individuals; and as a result work better to navigate the insanity of our industries.

speakers.bio: iOS Software Engineer. Ex-Radio DJ. Nigh-Podcaster. Philosopher.
speakers.name: Andrei Freeman

sessions.title: Embracing the Different

sessions.description: We strive to write great code and create apps that delight users. But anger, frustration, and even fear can lead us down a path to the dark side. Through stories and examples, weâ€™ll explore how the success of our technology is not just in the code that we write, but also in how we treat our fellow coders.

speakers.bio: Mac and iOS developer, trainer, and songwriter. Front man of James Dempsey and the Breakpoints. Occasional quip vendor.
speakers.name: James Dempsey

sessions.title: The Dark Side

sessions.description: Developers have referred to the App Store Review process as a black box, one that can’t be understood. In this talk, I’ll share the lessons we learned from the inside of the App Store, and how we managed to help change the world, one app at a time.

speakers.bio: Currently spending most of my time kiteboarding, angel investing, and working on some new augmented reality technology.
speakers.name: Phillip Shoemaker

sessions.title: Lessons from the App Store

sessions.description: Cloud Firestore is the next-generation document-object database in the cloud from Firebase. In this workshop, we'll help you understand all of the features of Cloud Firestore, and how to best use it in developing production ready scalable apps. This workshop will provide you with a general introduction to NoSQL databases, and then will cover more advanced topics like querying, transactions, security rules, offline support, pagination, and more!

speakers.bio: Developer Advocate at @Google. Lover of all things @Firebase and iOS.
speakers.name: Jen Person

sessions.title: Cloud Firestore Workshop
